channel.title: Sony Vegas meets Youtube!
channel.description:
Just to start off, this is a question :)
K, I see people edit with sony vegas all the time and post it on youtube
[b]Problem:[/b] When, I "Render" [Finish] the movie it always comes past 100mb [Youtube's size limit]
Any help?
[How would I make the file size smaller, but keep it in the same state?]

item.title: Sony Vegas meets Youtube!
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

[quote=“VB6 FTW, post:10, topic:134625”][quote author=The Un-Named link=topic=186022.msg1683163#msg1683163 date=1187418565]
Here’s some tips:

Try to keep visual quality in a reasonable format, .avi files are usually ridiculously high(kind of like the bitmaps of the video editing portal), generally you want to keep your video quality high, or even medium, BUT ALWAYS KEEP THE AUDIO ON HIGH, I cannot stress this more, since sound doesn’t add much size to the video.

Here’s a basic guide of video formats and their usage:

HIGH IN SIZE:
DV-AVI - 1 Hour of DV-AVI files can be up to 12GB (yes, you saw correct, 12GB!!!)
MPEG-2 - This is generally for putting on DVD discs for home use, rather than internet use.
DivX - This is best for torrents or simply videos for small harddrives.

MEDIUM IN SIZE:
MPEG-1 - This is probably best for video CD’s, or if you have a ridiculous harddrive size.

LOW IN SIZE(best for internet streaming):
RealVideo - Not suggested. It’s a pain in the ass.
WMV - Probably the best for internet streaming.

Small note: be expected to produce multiple copies to find the best video + sound : size ratio.
[/quote]

lolling Here’s a tip, BECOME A MEMBER.[/quote]

Of what?

[quote=“jme_009, post:9, topic:134625”]WMV’s seem to hate youtube, for me anyways. It turns super blocky.

I think youtube even says that divx is the best to use. So I usually convert to divx and I haven’t had any problems. Although any videos I had were only several mintues or less.[/quote]

I would say use DivX for anything, but I’m not sure how big the files get. I know they can be pretty large(I got a few files on my hardrive, 350+mb for 20 or so minutes on average quality. Have you tried producing the video in .wmv so it’s low in size then to something else, like .avi so the .avi is about the same size?

Read full topic

item.title: Sony Vegas meets Youtube!
item.dc:creator: @Divine-Devil Divine-Devil
item.description:
@Divine-Devil wrote:

Yeah I think I’m right ermm…Hold on [Uh oh]

“All videos uploaded to YouTube have a 100MB file size limit. The longer the video is, the more compression will be required to fit it into that size. For that reason, most videos on YouTube are under five minutes long and there is a 10-minute length limit for all videos.”

Gah, Mine was 800mb?! wtf?

Read full topic

item.title: Sony Vegas meets Youtube!
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

Er, youtube has a 1 mb limit? 1 mb is a pretty damn small file for movies.

I’ve uploaded 20+ mb files to youtube before, so maybe you need to double check.

edit: Just so I don’t look like a fool, he edited his post to say 100.

Read full topic
